of many developing governments and/or increased the likelihood of debt stress. With many vulnerable
ing burdened with higher financing costs, this limited fiscal space further shrinks

Considering the need for responses to both, short
current G20/IMF/World Bank debt service suspension initiatives are focused the liquidity issue rather
than underlying problems of more structural nature of many low
ensure fiscal space for climate action in the coming decade a mix b
liabilities, extended debt levels and sustainable lending practices including new solidarity structures
need to be considered in addition to higher levels of bilateral and multilateral lending to reduce
l markets and to bridge the availability of sustainably structured loans for highly
vulnerable and indebted countries. More standardised debt
climate swaps, a higher share of GDP
linked bonds or structures ensuring (partial) debt cancellation in case c
climate change impacts/shocks appear possible. The “hurricane” clause introduced by Grenada, or
wider natural disaster clauses provide issuers with an option to defer payments of interest and principal
in the event of a qualify
ing natural disaster and can reduce short
. A mainstreaming of such clauses has been pushed by various international institutions.
The collective action clause might be a good example of a loan/debt term which became market
standard. Definition of triggers is likely the most complex challenge in t
swaps is still very limited and not mainstreamed but
offers significant potential if used correctly
climate/nature swaps have been seen in r
in international climate cooperation and in bilateral contexts, however, not (yet) to an extent addressing
transparency with regard to the additionality of financed climate action, uncertainty with regard to own
resource constraints and ODA accountability remain as barrier for a massive scale
(Mitchell 2015; Fuller et al. 2018; Essers et al. 2021)
limitation of the use of debt
based instruments as a response to climate
Ensuring efficient debt restructuring and debt relief in events of extreme shocks and imminent over
indebtedness and sovereign debt default are further crucial elements with a joint responsibility
. In this context, the Commonwealth Secretariat flagged that
the diversification of the lender portfolio made debt restructuring more difficult with more and more
and the UN AAAA raising concerns about
cooperative creditors and disruption of timely completion of debt restructuring
This is a side effect of a stronger use of capital markets, which need to be carefully considered in the
context of sovereign bond issuances (see also 15.6.7).
. The debate around stranded assets focuses strongly on the loss of val
assets for investors (see Section 15.6.1, para. on the assessment of transition risk and carbon stranded

a major economic burden for states and hence the tax payers”
. Assets include not only financial assets but also infrastructure, equipment,
